newsitem.title: USA: Toyota ups U.S. Toyota division prices.
newsitem.headline: Toyota ups U.S. Toyota division prices.

text.p: Toyota Motor Corp. raised the stakes in the competitive market for mid-sized cars Tuesday by announcing price cuts of up to 4 percent on its all-new 1997 Camry.

The manufacturer's suggested price of a base four-cylinder CE Camry with manual transmission is now $16,818, including delivery charges of $420, down 2 percent from the sticker price on an entry-level 1996 Camry.
The new price is also almost $200 below the $18,545 base price of a rival 1997 Taurus G from Ford Motor Co., although the Taurus comes with an automatic transmission and a six-cylinder engine.
The Japanese automaker also dropped sticker prices on its top-of-the-line Camry XLE V6 by 4 percent, to $24,438 from $25,458.

Toyota's average 1997 model year prices on a comparably equipped basis will rise 0.7 percent, or $135, from the 1996 year, not including the Camry or Supra prices. The division had no mid-year price hikes during the 1996 model year.

Toyota's prices, taking advantage of a weaker Japanese yen that makes it cheaper to produce vehicles in Japan, are below those of Detroit's Big Three for the upcoming model year, which formally begins Oct. 1.
Ford hiked prices an average of 1.2 percent. General Motors Corp. prices rose 1.7 percent, while Chrysler Corp. boosted its prices an average of 1.9 percent.

George Magliano, an analyst with the WEFA Group, a New York-based industry consultant, said the new Camry prices will shake things up in the mid-size car market and have a ripple effect in the less expensive compact market as well.
"Everybody is going to have to go along with this," he said. "It's going to have to be met in the marketplace. This is too big a deal and too aggressive a price move just to pass off."

The conservative styling of Toyota's all-new Camry shows the Japanese automaker is moving in the opposite direction of the ultra-curved Taurus, which Ford designed with unique oval headlights and rear window.
While Ford loaded its new Taurus, introduced a year ago, with expensive options, Toyota officials stressed the new Camry's price value.

"Dramatic improvements in design, engineering and manufacturing have allowed us to offer our customers great Toyota value at a very competitive price," Toyota Division general manager David Illingworth said in a statement.
Toyota said, however, it raised prices on its popular new sport utility vehicles. The 4Runner now starts at $21,208, up 2 percent, and the RAV4 starts at $16,588, a rise of 1.1 percent.
